Gazan families face painful process of identifying Palestinian bodies returned by Israel
subhead: Lacking access to advanced forensic technology, medical examiners have to rely on the vigilance of the families of the missing to identify their loved ones, as Israel returned the bodies without any information about their identities.

title: Alassane Ouattara, reelected president of Côte d'Ivoire, is France's last major ally in Africa
subhead: The head of state, who was reelected for a fourth term on October 27, has been close to French presidents since Nicolas Sarkozy, to whom he owes his rise to power in 2011. France remains the leading investor in Côte d'Ivoire.

title: Far right poised for victory ahead of elections in the Netherlands
subhead: Dutch voters will be heading to the polls on Wednesday, for the second time in 11 months. Geert Wilders, leader of the Party for Freedom, hopes to turn the vote into a referendum on his anti-immigration platform. But the refusal of the right-wing Liberal and Christian Democratic parties to govern alongside Wilders could prevent him from becoming prime minister.
byline: By Jean-Pierre Stroobants (The Hague, special correspondent)

title: Controversy swirls around Romania's new 'National Cathedral,' now the largest in the Orthodox world
subhead: After 15 years of construction, the Romanian People's Salvation Cathedral now towers over Bucharest, having opened its doors to the public on Sunday. A source of pride for many Romanians, it has also drawn criticism for its cost, which was largely funded by public money.

title: Louvre heist: 'To think we could replace the works with replicas is almost to deny what they are'
subhead: Olivier Gabet, director of the Louvre Museum's decorative arts department, says that, far beyond their insurance value, the stolen jewels have aesthetic, artistic, national heritage and historical significance.

title: 'Why did they run from the police?': 20 years after two French teens' deaths, the question is as relevant as ever
subhead: For many people of color, fleeing a police stop has become a reflex. Sociologists say this risky behavior stems from the rise in incidents of police violence.

title: European industry caught in crossfire of China's rare earths war
subhead: Western technology sectors, including automotive, defense, aerospace, energy and chemicals, have raised the alarm over Beijing's new restrictions on the export of these strategic minerals.
byline: By Bastien Bonnefous, Sophie Fay, Adrien Pécout and Olivier Pinaud

title: Mouhamadou Fall, first French athlete to join Enhanced Games: 'For me, it's not doping, but a chance to learn more about the human body's limits'
subhead: The French sprinter announced Thursday that he has signed up for the Enhanced Games, an event where doping is permitted – even encouraged. In an interview with Le Monde, the multiple French champion in the 100 m and 200 m explains his decision.
